Efficient hydrogenation of dinitronaphthalene to diaminonaphthalene over Pt-Ru-FeOX/C catalyst: Mechanistic and kinetic studies Weixing Ming Writing – original draft Formal analysis Data curation a c d Zhankuo Guo Investigation Formal analysis c Dong Liu Formal analysis c Yanan Zhao Formal analysis b Dongmao Yan Writing – review & editing Formal analysis Data curation b ⁎ Tingwang An Data curation c Lu Ji Data curation c Wei Wei Formal analysis c Ge Xu Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Conceptualization d ⁎ a School of Materials Science and Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang, 110870, PR China School of Materials Science and Engineering Shenyang University of Technology Shenyang 110870 PR China aSchool of Materials Science and Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang, 110870, PR China b Shenyang University of Chemical Technology, Shenyang, 110142, PR China Shenyang University of Chemical Technology Shenyang 110142 PR China bShenyang University of Chemical Technology, Shenyang, 110142, PR China c Shenyang Research Institute of Chemical Industry, Shenyang 110021, PR China Shenyang Research Institute of Chemical Industry Shenyang 110021 PR China cShenyang Research Institute of Chemical Industry, Shenyang 110021, PR China d School of Environment and Chemical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang, 110870, PR China School of Environment and Chemical Engineering Shenyang University of Technology Shenyang 110870 PR China dSchool of Environment and Chemical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang, 110870, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Catalytic hydrogenation for synthesizing naphthalene diamine is eco-friendly, but developing efficient catalysts remains great challenges. In this work, the efficient conversion of dinitronaphthalene to diaminonaphthalene was achieved over a Pt-Ru-FeOX nanocluster catalyst supported on activated carbon, which was synthesized via a deposition method. 1,5-dinitronaphthalene (1,5-DNN) attained complete conversion with a selectivity of 98.73 % towards 1,5-diaminonaphthalene (1,5-DAN), resulting in a yield rate of 25.85 mmol/gmetal·s over 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst. The catalyst showed remarkable stability while maintaining high activity over five cycles (yield rate > 23.98 mmol/gmetal·s). Combined characterization (XPS, H2-TPR, Color change of WO3) and density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that the improved performance arose from the enhancing the adsorption and dissociation of H2, favoring the adsorption for -NO2 groups of 5-nitro-1-naphthylamine and 1,5-DNN. The tandem reaction pathway from 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DAN via intermediate 5-nitro-1-naphthylamine was clarified through LC-MS, FT-IR, and NMR analyses. Furthermore, the kinetics were elucidated to provide a profound understanding of the reaction mechanism and rate-determining steps. The research showed the Pt-Ru-FeOX catalytic system excels in hydrogenation of various aromatic dinitrocompounds, demonstrating its wide applicability. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Synergistic catalysis Hydrogen spillover Hydrogenation kinetics 1,5-dinitronaphthalene 1,5-diaminonaphthalene Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction 1,5-diaminonaphthalene (1,5-DAN) and 1,8-diaminonaphthalene (1,8-DAN) are two crucial isomers of diaminonaphthalene employed in the synthesis of high-value products including advanced dyes, high-performance polyurethanes, photosensitive materials, and specialty pharmaceuticals [1–4]. Traditional methods for reducing aromatic nitro compounds, such as those utilizing iron powder and sulfonates, are often hindered by complex pathways, significant organic waste generation, and low yields [5]. Conversely, catalytic hydrogenation reduction presents a more sustainable and economically viable approach, characterized by improved atom economy. Recent advancements have markedly improved the activity and selectivity of catalysts used in the hydrogenation of aromatic nitro compounds. These improvements have been realized through several methodologies, including the preparation and modification of supports, multi-metal alloying, and doping with both metallic and non-metallic elements [6–11]. For example, acid-modified carbon nanotubes have been demonstrated to introduce an increased number of oxygen-containing functional groups, thereby enhancing the dispersion of active nickel. The nickel-supported catalyst exhibited improved catalytic activity in the hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN, achieving a yield of 92.04 % for 1,5-DAN [12]. In a similar vein, catalysts synthesized using nitrogen-functionalized activated carbon modified the particle size of nickel, influencing its chemical state distribution, and exhibited high catalytic activity, achieving a yield of 94.75 % for 1,5-DAN [13]. Huang et al. implemented a strategy incorporating metal additives to inhibit the sintering of active nickel, thereby increasing the proportion of effective nickel on the support surface and enhancing its reduction capability, which resulted in a yield of 95.63 % for 1,5-DAN [14]. Furthermore, a nano-Pd sponge catalyst synthesized through a solvent dissolution method demonstrated a well-developed pore structure with a greater number of exposed active sites, achieving a 99 % conversion of 1,5-DNN and a 96 % selectivity for 1,5-DAN [15]. Despite these advancements, significant challenges persist in the research on catalysts for the hydrogenation of 1,5-DAN to 1,5-DAN, particularly concerning catalytic activity and selectivity. These challenges mainly arise from the electronic structure modification during nitro-to-amino group conversion, where the strongly electron-withdrawing -NO2 group transforms into an electron-donating -NH2 moiety. This transformation reduces the electron deficiency of the aromatic ring, thereby impeding the reduction of the second nitro group [16,17]. Additionally, the presence of toxic compounds, such as sulfur-containing substances introduced from upstream naphthalene, can poison the catalyst, leading to a marked decline in its activity and selectivity [18,19]. However, as a reducible oxide, iron oxide serves as a pivotal mediator for hydrogen spillover, facilitating active hydrogen migration. Concurrently, iron oxide incorporation modulates the electronic environment of Pt active sites, thereby strengthening -NO2 group adsorption and significantly enhancing catalytic performance [20–22]. Furthermore, the strong sulfur-binding affinity of Fe2O3 preferentially captures trace sulfide contaminants, effectively shielding Pt sites from poisoning and ensuring long-term catalytic stability [23–25]. This synergistic effect leads to exceptional activity and selectivity in nitroarene hydrogenation. In this study, a highly efficient Pt-Ru-FeOX nanocluster catalyst supported on activated carbon was successfully prepared. The effects of Pt electronic environment alteration, hydrogen spillover and the adsorption of H2, 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine and 1,5-DNN on the activity of the hydrogenation reaction were investigated by combined characterizations and DFT calculations. Furthermore, the reaction pathways and the kinetics of the hydrogenation process were explored. The hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN can be considered as a tandem process, and the intermediate 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine to 1,5-DAN was confirmed as the rate determining step of the overall process. The easily prepared catalyst showed excellent performance for aromatic dinitro compounds, suggesting promising utility in industrial processes. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Raw materials The reagents utilized in the experiment comprised toluene (99.5 %), ruthenium (III) chloride (RuCl3) with a ruthenium content of 37.5 %, ferrous chloride (FeCl2) at 99.5 % purity, chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6·6H2O) containing 37.5 % platinum, and 1,5-dinitronaphthalene (1,5-DNN) with 99 % purity. All reagents were procured from Xilong Chemical Co., Ltd. (Sichuan, China). The activated carbon was supplied by Shenyang Chemical Research Institute Co., Ltd. High-purity hydrogen (H2, 99.999 %) and high-purity nitrogen (N2, 99.999 %), as well as a hydrogen and nitrogen gas mixture (comprising 90 vol % N2 and 10 vol % H2), were procured from Shenyang Hongsheng Gas Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Pt-Ru-FeOX/C catalyst was synthesized using the following procedure: Initially, 1.0 g of activated carbon was added to a 100 mL round-bottom flask containing 50 mL of deionized water and subjected to ultrasonic dispersion for 10 min. Subsequently, a 0.125 M sodium carbonate aqueous solution was added dropwise to the flask until the pH reached 8. A 100 mL aqueous solution containing FeCl2, RuCl3, and H2PtCl6·6H2O was then introduced into the flask incrementally and at a slow pace under vigorous stirring, then maintained at 80 °C for 2 h. The mixture was isolated by centrifugation and thoroughly washed with deionized water until the supernatant conductivity decreased below 100 μS/cm. The resulting solid was oven-dried at 60 °C for 12 h, then reduced at 150 °C for 4 h in a tube furnace under a 10 % H2/90 % N2 reducing atmosphere (flow rate: 50 mL/min). The catalyst was designated as "x Pt-y Ru-z FeOX/C" or "x Pt-y Ru/C," where x, y, and z represent the mass fractions of Pt, Ru, and FeOX, respectively. It was important to note that for the physically mixed catalyst, the mass fraction of the metals was trebled to maintain consistent loaded mass. The single-metal catalysts, namely Pt/C, Ru/C, and FeOX/C, were synthesized using the same procedures outlined above, but with individual precursors. 2.3 Characterization The crystal phase and degree of crystallinity of the sample were analyzed using a Shimadzu LabX XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer, equipped with a copper target, Kα radiation source, and a nickel filter. The instrument was operated at a tube voltage of 40 kV and a tube current of 30 mA, with a scanning speed of 5° per minute over a range of 5° to 80° Additionally, the specific surface area, pore size distribution, and pore volume of the samples were assessed using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 HD88 physical adsorption analyzer. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm was measured at a temperature of 77.35 K, which corresponds to the boiling point of liquid nitrogen. The specific surface area of the sample was determined using the BET equation. The pore volume, pore-specific surface area, and external specific surface area were evaluated employing the t-plot method, whereas the pore size distribution was analyzed using the DFT Model. The morphological characteristics of the catalyst, along with the distribution of the active metal particles, were examined utilizing a scanning electron microscope (SEM) (JEOL, Japan Electronics Co., LTD, JSM-7610FPlus) and a transmission electron microscope (TEM) (JEOL, Japan Electronics Co., LTD, JEM-2100F). Additionally, observations were conducted using the JEOL and Thermo Talos F200X high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) from the United States. STEM-EDS elemental mapping and line-scanning analyses provided additional confirmation of the surface morphology, nanostructures, and elemental distribution of the catalysts. The metal valence states were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha). The metal of catalyst content was characterized using Agilent 5110 inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). The structure of the compound was analyzed employing several techniques: Liquid Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (LC-MS) with an Agilent 6230 TOF LC-MS system, Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR) using a Bruker ALPHA-T instrument, and Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy with a Jeol JNM-ECZ600R 600 MHz spectrometer. 2.4 Catalytic reaction The catalytic hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DAN was conducted in a 100 mL autoclave. In a typical procedure, 1,5-DNN was mixed with toluene and catalyst in the high-pressure reactor. Prior to each experimental run, the integrity of the reactor was verified by filling it with N2 to ensure that no leaks were present. Subsequently, H2 was introduced into the system three times consecutively to purge it, and the autoclave was then pressurized with 1.5 MPa of H2 when it reached the desired temperature. The reaction was terminated when the instantaneous hydrogen consumption dropped to zero. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was analyzed utilizing Liquid Chromatography (Agilent 1260). The quantity of the product was quantified with the application of the external standard method. The normalized yield rates of aromatic amines were calculated using the following equation [26]. (1) Yield rate = reactant amount ( converted ) × product selectivity ( reaction time × metal mass ) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization results The catalytic performance was found to be highly dependent on reduction conditions. Through systematic optimization of reduction parameters, 150 °C was identified as the optimal temperature when reducing the catalyst for 3 h under a H2 atmosphere, which improved the yield rate by 20.2 % compared to samples reduced at lower temperatures (100 °C), as shown in Fig. S1a. While the yield rate remained stable at 250 °C, elevation to 400 °C caused significant performance degradation, which comparative TEM analysis with the catalyst reduced at 150 °C (Fig. S2a) confirmed to be caused by metal sintering (Fig. S2c). Additionally, the investigation of reduction time effects revealed that the yield rate plateaued after 2 h of reduction (Fig. S1b), indicating that this duration was sufficient for precursor reduction. The findings indicate that the optimal reduction protocol (2 h at 150 °C under H2 flow) enables both full reduction of metallic species and minimal nanoparticle aggregation, consequently affording the catalyst with superior catalytic activity. The analysis of the structure and elemental distribution of the Ru-Pt-FeOX nanoparticles was conducted utilizing HAADF-STEM and STEM-EDS. Notably, an absence of large metal particles on the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst surface was found under the bright-field mode of TEM (Fig. 1 a). High-resolution TEM imaging (Fig. 1 b) revealed that the average size of the metal particles was 1.7 ± 0.5 nm (Fig. 1 c). The findings further demonstrated that the metal nanoparticles were well-dispersed and anchored onto the activated carbon under dark field conditions (Fig. 1 d). However, a densely packed metallic nanoparticle aggregate with a characteristic dimension of 30 nanometers was observed in Fig. 1 e and Fig. S2d. The particle exhibited a highly compact morphology and was composed of individual metallic nanoparticles with diameters ranging from 2 to 3 nanometers. HAADF-STEM images and STEM-EDS mapping results (Fig. 1 f-j) further corroborated that the three metallic elements (Pt, Ru, and Fe) exhibit a uniformly mixed state within the clusters. The mass contents of Pt, Ru, and Fe elements on the catalyst surface were measured to be 1.16 %, 0.18 %, and 0.24 %, respectively, as shown in Fig. S2e-f and Table S1. EDS line scans (Fig. 1 k-l) showed that while the areas of highest intensity for Pt, Ru, and Fe were near each other, they did not overlap, thereby indicating that the nanoparticles forms a Pt-Ru-FeOX nanocluster instead of an alloy. The results imply that the three uniform particles in the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst may have a positive synergistic effect, which modulates the local electronic environment of the active Pt sites, consequently exerting a beneficial influence on the catalytic performance [26–28]. In addition, SEM images demonstrated that the predominant portion of the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst ranged from tens to hundreds of microns in size, as illustrated in Fig. S2g. This morphological characteristic was particularly advantageous for industrial implementation, as it significantly reduced filtration resistance while simultaneously minimizing the risk of catalyst leakage. More importantly, the internal architecture of catalyst displayed an open, highly porous structure, as evidenced in Fig. S2h and S2i, which promoted efficient mass transfer by substantially lowering diffusion barriers for both reactant ingress and product egress. The element valence and metal-support interaction were investigated using XPS. In the Pt 4f XPS spectra (Fig. 2 a), the Pt 4f7/2 spectra showed binding energies at 71.2 eV, 72.0 eV, and 73.1 eV, corresponding to Pt0, Pt2+, and Pt4+, respectively. Similarly, in the Pt 4f5/2 spectra, these species had binding energies of 74.5 eV, 75.4 eV, and 76.5 eV, respectively [29,30]. The Pt 4f spectra (Fig. 2 a) demonstrated positive binding energy shifts of +0.23 eV and +0.37 eV for 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C and 1.2Pt-0.4FeOX/C respectively, relative to the 1.2Pt/C reference, while 1.2Pt-0.2Ru/C showed only a marginal shift. These shifts indicated a decrease in the Fermi level or an increase in d-vacancies, suggesting electron deficiency in Pt particles due to electron transfer [31–33]. Complementary Ru 3p spectra (Fig. 2 b) exhibited even more pronounced shifts, with +0.47 eV and +0.42 eV positive displacements for 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C and 0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C respectively, demonstrating strong FeOX-mediated electronic perturbation of Ru. The relatively small +0.28 eV shift observed in 1.2Pt-0.2Ru/C could be attributed to the electronic perturbation of Ru by Pt, which exhibited slightly higher electronegativity. In addition, a systematic evolution of iron oxidation states across the catalyst series was studied by XPS analysis. In Fig. 2 c, the Fe 2p3/2 binding energies at 705.9 eV, 709.7 eV (710.8 eV), and 711.6 eV (712.7 eV) correspond to Fe0, Fe2+ and Fe3+, respectively [34]. While the reference 0.4FeOX/C sample exhibited predominantly Fe3+ species with minor Fe2+ contributions, the introduction of noble metals induced significant changes. In the 0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C and 1.2Pt-0.4FeOX/C catalysts, it was observed that a progressive decrease in Fe3+ content accompanied by a corresponding increase in Fe2+ species. Most remarkably, the ternary 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst demonstrated partial reduction to metallic Fe0, as unequivocally confirmed by the appearance of characteristic XPS signatures at lower binding energies. These findings suggest electron transfer from Pt and Ru nanoparticles to the FeOX species in the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C system, a phenomenon also reported for Pt/γ-Fe2O3 and 0.3 % Pt-4 % Fe/C catalysts [35,36]. Simultaneous electron transfer from Ru to Pt species occurs, revealing a dynamic charge redistribution process characteristic of the ternary Pt-Ru-FeOX nanocluster system. The electron-deficient Pt and Ru centers could act as electrophilic or Lewis acid site favoring the adsorption of 1,5-DNN and 5-nitro-1-naphthylamine and subsequent activation of the NO band [31,37]. Iron oxide, as a reducible oxide, serves as a transportation hub for hydrogen overflow during hydrogenation and exhibits a greater capacity for hydrogen spillover compared to irreducible oxide supports [38]. These results indicate that the Pt-Ru-FeOX nanocluster system displays pronounced synergistic effects, which simultaneously enhance H2 activation, promote 1,5-DNN adsorption, and enable efficient hydrogen spillover, all of which contribute to its superior catalytic performance. The synergistic interactions among multimetallic components not only facilitate reactant activation through electronic structure modulation of the primary active metal, but also significantly influence catalytic activity and selectivity by promoting hydrogen spillover phenomena [39–42]. This process involves the generation of mobile active hydrogen species at metal sites, their rapid migration across supporting matrices (e.g., carbonaceous materials, metal oxides), and subsequent interaction with reactant molecules, thereby enhancing hydrogenation efficiency [43]. Crucially, this mechanism simultaneously reduces the energy barriers for both hydrogen dissociation and hydrogen transfer, enabling selective hydrogenation under mild reaction conditions [44]. The color change of WO3 was employed to verify hydrogen spillover, as tungsten oxide can be easily reduced by atomic hydrogen. As depicted in Fig. 2 d, all fresh catalysts exhibited a light gray appearance when mixed with WO3. Under mild conditions (50 °C, 0.2 MPa H2, 0.5 h), the physical mixture of WO3 and catalysts underwent a visible color transition from light gray to blue, with the mixture of WO3 and 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst displaying the most pronounced dark blue color, indicating strong reduction. However, the WO3 powder retained its yellow coloration after H2 treatment. This inter-site spillover could play a pivotal role in enhancing the hydrogenation reaction activity of the catalyst. H2-TPR is also regarded as an effective analytical technique for demonstrating the presence of the hydrogen spillover and utilized to examine the reduction of oxides in catalytic materials. As illustrated in Fig. 2 e, no reduction peaks corresponding to Pt and Ru were detected for the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst at temperatures ranging from 75 to 150 °C. This observation suggested that Pt and Ru were nearly reduced during the preparation process and predominantly exist in their zero valent states. These outcomes aligned with the findings of the XPS analysis. Notably, the 0.4FeOX/C catalyst exhibited two distinct reduction peaks. The peak observed at the lower temperature of 420 °C was attributed to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, whereas the peak at the higher temperature, approximately 560 °C, corresponded to the further reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO and metallic Fe (Fe0) [45]. However, the reduction peak of Fe2O3 in the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst was significantly shifted to a lower temperature region (320 °C). The results demonstrate that the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst exhibits a pronounced inter-site hydrogen spillover phenomenon among Pt, Ru, and Fe species.The active hydrogen species formed on Pt and Ru sites underwent spillover to the FeOX surface [39,46,47]. Consequently, the Pt-Ru-FeOX active sites undoubtedly demonstrate a distinct synergistic effect that facilitates the hydrogenation process. The XRD patterns of the different samples were shown in Fig. 2 f. The activated carbon support exhibited characteristic diffraction peaks at 24.3° and 35.4°, corresponding to the planes of graphitized carbon [36]. The characteristic diffraction peaks at about 39.9°, corresponding to the (111) planes of metallic Pt, were observed in both the 1.2Pt/C and 1.2Pt-0.2Ru/C samples [48]. In contrast, the absence of this peak in the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C sample suggested an even higher dispersion of Pt, beyond the detection limit of X-ray diffraction. Moreover, the absence of characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to metallic Ru (JCPDS 00-001-1253; 38.68° (100), 58.88° (102), 69.68° (110)) or Fe2O3 (JCPDS 33-0644; 24.3° (012), 33.3° (104), 35.7° (110), 41.0° (113), 49.6° (024), 54.2° (116), 62.6° (214), 64.1° (300)) in the XRD pattern of the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst suggests that these components were uniformly dispersed within the activated carbon matrix together with Pt [36,49]. This conclusion was further supported by the TEM characterization results presented earlier. To further examine the structural characteristics of the samples, N2 physisorption measurements were performed. The isotherms depicted in Fig S3a indicated that the adsorption and desorption processes display irreversible behavior at relative pressures (P/P0 = 0.4−1.0), which was characteristic of mesoporous materials. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations and the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method were employed to determine the pore-size distributions and specific surface areas of the samples, respectively. Although the mesopore size distribution of all samples spans 3−20 nm, the catalysts demonstrate a pronounced decrease in pore volume relative to activated carbon, particularly for mesopores of 6−12 nm (Fig. S3b and Table S2). 3.2 Catalyst evaluation The catalytic performance of different catalysts for of 1,5-DNN hydrogenation at 80 °C and 1.5 MPa of H2 was presented in Table 1 . The yield rates of 1,5-DAN were 0.23 mmol/gmetal·s and 2.12 mmol/gmetal·s over catalysts of 1.2FeOX/C and 1.2Ru/C respectively, with corresponding 1,5-DAN selectivities of 56.34 % and 86.22 %, indicating their inferior activity in 1,5-DNN hydrogenation. In comparison, the yield rate of 1,5-DAN was 19.24 mmol/gmetal·s via 1.2Pt/C, with a selectivity of 97.32 %, highlighting that the Pt was the main active component in the catalyst for the nitro hydrogenation reaction. In addition, the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru/C exhibited a higher yield rate of 21.67 mmol/gmetal·s attribute to the efficient inter-site spillover and the enhanced capacity for hydrogen activation at the dual active sites [26]. It was obvious that 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C showed the highest catalytic performance in all samples, achieving a complete conversion of 1,5-DNN and a selectivity of 98.73 % towards 1,5-DAN, attaining the yield rate of 25.85 mmol/gmetal·s. However, the yield rate (16.27 mmol/gmetal·s) for the 1,5-DAN product was not be significantly improved through the physical combination of catalysts 3.6Pt/C, 0.6Ru/C and 1.2FeOX/C. The results highlight the critical role of synergistic interactions of the Pt-Ru-FeOX system in benefiting the hydrogenation. The high-conversion stability tests better reveal the catalyst's ability to maintain both high selectivity and conversion under conditions that closely mimic industrial applications. Therefore, to assess the operational stability under simulated industrial conditions (T = 80 °C, P = 1.5 MPa), the catalysts were subjected to multiple recycling tests at a high conversion rate, with detailed performance evolution shown in Fig. 3 . The 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst exhibited superior performance, maintaining both complete conversion (100 %) of 1,5-DNN and high selectivity (98.60 %) for 1,5-DAN over five cycles (Fig. 3 a). Although the monometallic 1.2Pt/C catalyst similarly achieved complete conversion, its product selectivity (87.25 %) was markedly inferior at the fifth cycle (Fig. 3 b). Most significantly, the Pt-Ru-FeOX system demonstrated exceptional stability, with the yield rate decreasing only marginally from 25.85 to 23.98 mmol/gmetal·s (7.2 % reduction) after five cycles. In contrast, the Pt/C catalyst suffered a 34.9 % decline in yield rate (from 19.24 to 12.53 mmol/gmetal·s) (Fig. 3 c). Detailed experimental data were provided in the supporting information (Table S3 and Table S4). The 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst further exhibited robust stability over a conclusion substantiated by comprehensive characterization through TEM and ICP analyses, as shown in Fig. S1 a-b. The recycled catalyst with an average particle size of 1.8 ± 0.6 nm, which was virtually indistinguishable from the fresh catalyst. This remarkable consistency in nanoparticle dimensions, coupled with the sustained high degree of metal dispersion, provides compelling evidence for the exceptional structural stability of the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst. ICP analysis revealed a marginal decrease in Pt content from 1.17 wt % (fresh catalyst) to 1.14 wt % (recycled catalyst) (Table S5). Considering that Pt metal particles demonstrate instability exclusively under strongly alkaline conditions—which were absent in our reaction system—and given the formation of more stable intermediate compounds (hydrazonaphthylamine and azoxy compounds) during hydrogenation, we attribute the observed Pt content variation predominantly to the persistent retention of refractory organic species rather than to actual metal leaching [12,50]. The metal-carbon interaction, while fundamentally governed by van der Waals forces, exhibited emergent collective mechanical stability that effectively immobilizes metallic nanoparticles on the carbon support which consequently ensured preservation of active metal content during reaction. Therefore, the structural stability of the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst is crucial for maintaining its high activity during multiple recycling cycles. Moreover, the exceptional stability can be rationalized through the synergistic interactions in the Pt-Ru-FeOX system, wherein the superior sulfur-binding affinity of iron oxide preferentially sequesters trace sulfide contaminants, thereby protecting Pt active sites from poisoning. 3.3 Reaction routes To investigate the reaction pathway and product distribution, time-dependent experiments were conducted over a duration of 65 min, as depicted in Fig. 4 a. At the initial stage (10 min), the conversion of 1,5-DNN reached 30.9 %, while the concentration of 1,5-DAN remained negligible (about 0.26 %). Notably, a intermediate species was detected, accumulating to a substantial concentration of approximately 33 %. Following its maximum accumulation, the intermediate concentration exhibited a gradual decline, concomitant with a pronounced increase in 1,5-DAN. These results provide strongly evidence for a sequential two-step hydrogenation mechanism, wherein 1,5-DNN undergoes initial hydrogenation to form the intermediate species, followed by its subsequent conversion to the 1,5-DAN. In order to clarify the structure of the intermediate, purification was performed utilizing silica gel column chromatography with a hexane/ethyl acetate (2:1) elution system [51]. The purified compound was subsequently characterized by LC-MS, FT-IR, and NMR. LC-MS analysis showed a molecular ion peak corresponding to M = 188, with the fragmentation pattern displayed in Fig. S4. Additionally, FT-IR spectral analysis (Fig. 4 b) demonstrated characteristic absorption bands at 3420 cm-1 (NH stretching) and 1625 cm-1 (NH bending), confirming the presence of an aromatic amine. Additionally, distinct peaks at 1532 cm-1 and 1353 cm-1 were assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the nitro group, respectively [26,46]. The CN stretching vibration was identified at approximately 870 cm−1. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy provided further structural confirmation, as shown in Fig. S5. The 1H NMR spectrum (600 MHz, CDCl3) exhibited characteristic signals at δ = 8.13 (m, 2H), 7.91 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 1H), 7.49 (ddd, J = 8.5, 7.8, 6.0 Hz, 2H), 6.90 (m, 1H), and 4.28 (s, 2H). The 13C NMR spectrum (75 MHz, CDCl3) displayed resonances at δ = 147.48, 142.79, 130.11, 127.13, 126.17, 124.82, 123.72, 122.86, 113.56, and 111.32. The chemical shift values, proton multiplicity, and integration ratios were consistent with the reported spectroscopic data for 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine [51]. Consequently, a clear hydrogenation pathway for 1,5-DNN was elucidated, sequential reduction first to 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine and subsequently to 1,5-DAN. 3.4 hydrogenation kinetics The time-dependent experimental results indicated that the hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DAN followed a tandem reaction mechanism. Therefore, the hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN and 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine could be considered as two relatively independent processes, enabling the separate determination of their respective kinetic parameters. To establish intrinsic reaction kinetics free from mass transport artifacts, we systematically evaluated and eliminated potential diffusion limitations through controlled experiments. External mass transfer effects were investigated by varying agitation speed (600–1800 rpm, Fig. S6a) and hydrogen pressure (0.2–2.5 MPa, Fig. S6b). The reaction rate exhibited strong dependence on stirring speed below 1500 rpm (Fig. S6a), indicating significant mass transfer resistance during hydrogen diffusion from the gas-liquid interface through the bulk phase to the catalyst surface. Above 1500 rpm, the rate plateaued, confirming the absence of external diffusion constraints. Hence, 1500 rpm was selected for all kinetic studies. Reaction rates were measured at H2 pressures of 0.2–2.5 MPa (Fig. S6b). A near-linear increase in reaction rate occurred when the pressure rises from 0.2 to 1.5 MPa. However, when the pressure was further increased incrementally to 1.5 MPa, no significant change in the rate of reaction was observed. It implied that the surface of the catalyst became saturated. Subsequent kinetic experiments used ≧ 1.5 MPa H2 to avoid gas-phase mass transfer limitations. Internal diffusion was verified to be negligible, as the catalyst's nanoscale thickness (850 nm, Fig. S2i) was substantially below the characteristic 10 µm threshold where pore diffusion limitations typically emerge [52]. These comprehensive validations ensure that subsequent kinetic measurements were conducted under conditions free from both external and internal diffusion limitations. Previous studies have established that the hydrogenation of nitroaromatics to aromatic amines typically follows first-order reaction kinetics [53,54]. Accordingly, a kinetic model for the hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DAN was developed based on first-order reaction kinetics, and the apparent activation energies (Ea) for each step were calculated. The activation energies were determined to be 28.71 kJ/mol for the hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN to 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine and 38.73 kJ/mol for the hydrogenation of 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine to 1,5-DAN, as illustrated in Fig. 5 a-b. Additional details regarding the derivation of the kinetic model were provided in the supplementary information (Fig. S7a-b and Table S6). Notably, all kinetic data exhibited excellent linear correlations, with R2 values exceeding 0.99. The observed differences in reaction rates indicated that the hydrogenation of 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine to 1,5-DAN was the rate-determining step of the overall process. The preferential hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN to 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine, attributed to its lower activation energy, was consistent with the experimental data presented in Fig. 4 a. The synergistic effects among the Pt-Ru-FeOX system were further validated through a comparative analysis of rate constants, as depicted in Fig. 5 c. Kinetic studies reveal the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst achieves significantly higher hydrogenation rates (k1 = 1.98 h⁻1 for 1,5-DNN; k2 = 1.01 h⁻1 for 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine) versus bimetallic 1.2Pt-0.2Ru/C (Δk = +0.60 h⁻1 and +0.29 h⁻1) and monometallic 1.2Pt/C references (Δk = +0.80 h⁻1 and +0.42 h⁻1), highlighting the promotional role of FeOX in the hydrogenation. Additional details regarding the rate constants for the various catalysts are provided in the supplementary information (Fig. S7c-d and Table S7). Therefore, the Pt-Ru-FeOX sites undoubtably possess particular synergetic effect in expediting hydrogenation, where the facile inter-site spillover of H, favoring adsorption of -NO2 group and hydrogen dissociation play an important role, which has been confirmed by the results of H2-TPR, XPS and color change of WO3. 3.5 DFT calculation DFT calculations comparing the adsorption energies of H2 and 1,5-DNN on Pt active sites further elucidate the enhanced hydrogenation mechanism. The calculations employed an activated carbon and nanoclusters models, represented by a 8 × 8 graphene unit (128 carbon atoms) and three clusters (Pt3, Pt3-Ru1, and Pt3-Ru1-Fe2O3), respectively. Details of the calculations were provided in the supplementary information. Since Pt was recognized as the principal active site for the hydrogenation of nitro groups, the adsorption of H2 on the Pt sites of the catalyst surface was studied firstly. The adsorption energy of H2 in the Pt3-Ru1-Fe2O3/C catalyst was determined to be −2.85 eV, which was significantly higher than the values observed for Pt3/C (−1.04 eV) and Pt3-Ru1/C (−1.60 eV), indicating the Pt3-Ru1-Fe2O3/C catalyst was more accessible to the adsorption of H2, as depicted in Fig. 6 a [26,55]. The optimized configurations of H2 adsorption (top-view, Fig. S8a-c) and their associated HH bond elongation characteristics (front-view, Fig. S8e-g) were comprehensively shown in Fig. S8. It can be seen that the H1-H2 bond length over the Pt3-Ru1-Fe2O3/C catalyst was stretched to 2.02 Å, compared to the bond length of 0.75 Å in the free H2 molecule. This extension was also notably greater than that observed on the Pt3/C catalyst (1.88 Å) and the Pt3-Ru1/C catalyst (1.92 Å). This suggests that the H1-H2 bond was cleaved, forming two hydrogen atoms without requiring any energy input based on the adsorption structure [56–58]. In addition, DFT calculations elucidate the hydrogen adsorption behavior at Ru sites in the Pt3-Ru1-Fe2O3 systems as illustrated in Fig. S8d and Fig. S8h. The adsorption energies of H2 reach –1.70 eV for Pt3-Ru1-Fe2O3/C, with HH bond elongation to 1.98 Å. These findings demonstrate the exceptional capacity of Ru to promote hydrogen dissociation in the ternary system. Therefore, the Pt3-Ru1-Fe2O3 system profoundly enhanced the adsorption and dissociation of H2, facilitating hydrogen activation. Furthermore, the adsorption energies of 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine and 1,5-DNN binding via -NO2 groups to the Pt sites in the catalytic systems were shown in Fig. 6 b-c. The corresponding adsorption configurations (front-view) were shown in Fig. S9. The adsorption energy of 1,5-DNN on the Pt3-Ru1-Fe2O3/C surface was significantly more negative (–2.63 eV) compared to those on Pt3/C (–1.41 eV) and Pt3-Ru1/C (–1.64 eV). Similarly, the adsorption of 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine via its -NO2 group on Pt3-Ru1-Fe2O3/C also exhibited a much stronger interaction (–1.01 eV) than on Pt3/C (–0.68 eV) and Pt3-Ru1/C (–0.74 eV). Therefore, compared to Pt3/C and Pt3-Ru1/C, the Pt3-Ru1-Fe2O3/C catalyst exhibited the enhanced adsorption capacity for 1,5-DNN and 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine. The enhanced hydrogen adsorption and activation, coupled with optimized adsorption of both reactants and intermediates, jointly govern the improved hydrogenation activity. 3.6 Catalyst versatility To evaluate the versatility of the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst, the hydrogenation of various dinitroaromatic compounds was conducted under identical reaction conditions, with the results summarized in Table 2 . All substrates achieved complete conversion and high selectivity, demonstrating the superior catalytic efficiency of the Pt-Ru-FeOX system for the hydrogenation of aromatic dinitro compounds. The yield rates for 1,5-DAN and 1,8-DAN were comparable, reaching 25.85 mmol/gmetal·s and 24.35 mmol/gmetal·s, respectively. However, the yield rates for diaminobenzene were significantly lower than those for diaminonaphthalene. Specifically, the yield rates for o-diaminobenzene, m-diaminobenzene, and p-diaminobenzene were determined to be 19.40 mmol/gmetal·s, 21.54 mmol/gmetal·s, and 20.37 mmol/gmetal·s, respectively. This difference originates from stronger diminished electron deficiency in the aromatic ring induced by the electron-donating amine group, which passivates the ring and hinders reduction of the second nitro group [17]. Collectively, these results demonstrate that the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst exhibits high selectivity and efficiency for the hydrogenation of the aromatic dinitro compounds. 4 Conclusions A 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst supported on activated carbon was successfully prepared via a deposition method, yielding nanoparticles of active metal with an average size of (1.4 ± 0.2) nm. Under mild reaction conditions (80 °C, 1.5 MPa), the catalyst achieved complete conversion of 1,5-DNN (100 %) with exceptional selectivity (98.73 %) toward 1,5-DAN, corresponding to a yield rate of 25.85 mmol/gmetal·s. The catalyst exhibited high activity and stability over five cycles (yield rate > 23.98 mmol/gmetal·s). The outstanding performance was attributed to the strong synergistic interactions of the Pt-Ru-FeOX system. DFT calculations revealed that the Pt-Ru-FeOX nanocluster exhibited superior H2 activation and enhanced adsorption capacity for -NO2 groups of 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine and1,5-DNN. The experiments of WO3 color change provided direct evidence of the enhanced hydrogen spillover capability of the Pt-Ru-FeOX system, which significantly promoted hydrogenation efficiency. Additionally, The reaction pathway and mechanism for the tandem hydrogenation of 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DAN, via the intermediate 5-nitro-1-naphthylamine, were comprehensively elucidated using a combination of LC-MS, FT-IR, and NMR analyses. First-order kinetic models were employed to study the hydrogenation kinetics of 1,5-DNN and 5-nitro-1-naphthylamine, with calculated activation energies (Ea) of 28.71 kJ/mol and 38.73 kJ/mol, respectively. The hydrogenation of 5-nitro-1-naphthalenamine to 1,5-DAN was confirmed as the rate- determining step of the overall process. The synthesis method developed for the 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst was straightforward, making it highly suitable for industrial applications. Moreover, the catalyst exhibited superior performance in the hydrogenation of various aromatic dinitro compounds, signifying its broad applicability. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic hydrogenation for synthesizing naphthalene diamine is eco-friendly, but developing efficient catalysts remains great challenges. In this work, the efficient conversion of dinitronaphthalene to diaminonaphthalene was achieved over a Pt-Ru-FeOX nanocluster catalyst supported on activated carbon, which was synthesized via a deposition method. 1,5-dinitronaphthalene (1,5-DNN) attained complete conversion with a selectivity of 98.73 % towards 1,5-diaminonaphthalene (1,5-DAN), resulting in a yield rate of 25.85 mmol/gmetal·s over 1.2Pt-0.2Ru-0.4FeOX/C catalyst. The catalyst showed remarkable stability while maintaining high activity over five cycles (yield rate > 23.98 mmol/gmetal·s). Combined characterization (XPS, H2-TPR, Color change of WO3) and density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that the improved performance arose from the enhancing the adsorption and dissociation of H2, favoring the adsorption for -NO2 groups of 5-nitro-1-naphthylamine and 1,5-DNN. The tandem reaction pathway from 1,5-DNN to 1,5-DAN via intermediate 5-nitro-1-naphthylamine was clarified through LC-MS, FT-IR, and NMR analyses. Furthermore, the kinetics were elucidated to provide a profound understanding of the reaction mechanism and rate-determining steps. The research showed the Pt-Ru-FeOX catalytic system excels in hydrogenation of various aromatic dinitrocompounds, demonstrating its wide applicability.
